risk_factors.reasoning: 10 arrests and a conviction indicate a high likelihood of future criminal behavior.
Being 18 years old may increase the likelihood of engaging in risky behaviors, but it is not a strong predictor on its own.
Gender does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Race is not a strong predictor of criminal behavior, but it may play a role in some instances.
Being tall can make it easier to intimidate others and may increase the likelihood of being involved in physical confrontations, but it is not a strong predictor on its own.
Being overweight can lead to health problems and may make it harder for the individual to engage in physical activities, but it is not a strong predictor on its own.
Being single does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Living alone does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Having a GED certificate and not being enrolled in college does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Holding one job during the year does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Using drugs in the past four years (marijuana and cocaine) increases the likelihood of engaging in criminal behavior, particularly if the individual is not seeking help for their drug addiction.
Feeling depressed over the past month does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
Living with both biological parents in an urban area at a young age may have contributed to the individual's criminal behavior, but it is not a strong predictor on its own.
Considering that God has something to do with what happens to them personally does not have a significant impact on the likelihood of reoffending.
